name: Legal Entity
description: A Legal Entity is a registered organization that operates as a distinct business unit under legal authority, maintains its own financial records, and has the legal capacity to enter into contracts, own assets, employ workers, and conduct business operations. This can be a company, corporation, enterprise, firm, parent organization, subsidiary, LLC, partnership, or any other form of legally recognized business structure.

business_concepts.name: Company Registration
business_concepts.description: Company Registration is the legal process of establishing a new business entity by filing required documentation with government authorities to obtain legal recognition and authorization to operate. Also known as business incorporation, entity formation, or business establishment.

business_concepts.name: Corporate Governance
business_concepts.description: Corporate Governance is the system of rules, practices, and processes by which a company is directed and controlled, ensuring accountability, fairness, and transparency in the relationship between management, board of directors, shareholders, and stakeholders. Also referred to as corporate oversight, board governance, or compliance management.

business_concepts.name: Financial Reporting
business_concepts.description: Financial Reporting is the process of producing and distributing financial statements and reports that summarize a company's financial position, performance, and cash flows for external stakeholders such as investors, regulators, and tax authorities. Also known as fiscal reporting, financial disclosure, or corporate reporting.

business_concepts.name: Tax Management
business_concepts.description: Tax Management is the systematic planning, calculation, filing, and payment of all tax obligations including income tax, sales tax, payroll tax, and other levies required by tax authorities. Also referred to as tax compliance, tax administration, or fiscal obligation management.

name: Factory
description: A Factory is a physical manufacturing facility where production operations occur, containing production lines, machinery, workforce, and support systems to transform raw materials into finished products. Also referred to as plant, manufacturing site, production facility, manufacturing location, or production plant.

business_concepts.name: Production Scheduling
business_concepts.description: Production Scheduling is the planning process of assigning work orders to production lines, sequencing jobs, balancing capacity, setting start times, and creating an executable shop floor schedule that meets delivery commitments. Also known as shop floor scheduling, job sequencing, or manufacturing scheduling.

business_concepts.name: Capacity Planning
business_concepts.description: Capacity Planning is the strategic process of analyzing production capacity requirements against available capacity considering equipment, labor, and time constraints to identify gaps and make investment decisions. Also referred to as capacity analysis, resource planning, or production capacity management.

business_concepts.name: Shop Floor Control
business_concepts.description: Shop Floor Control is the execution management process of releasing work orders, tracking progress, managing priorities, resolving issues, and ensuring jobs flow efficiently through production operations. Also known as production control, manufacturing execution, or shop floor management.

business_concepts.name: Factory Performance Monitoring
business_concepts.description: Factory Performance Monitoring is the measurement and analysis process of tracking key manufacturing metrics including output volume, efficiency, quality rates, downtime, and OEE to provide visibility into factory performance and identify improvement opportunities. Also referred to as manufacturing metrics tracking, factory KPI monitoring, or production performance measurement.

name: Warehouse
description: A Warehouse is a physical facility used for storing and handling inventory including raw materials, work-in-progress, and finished goods, providing space, equipment, and systems for receiving, storage, picking, and shipping operations. Also referred to as distribution center, storage facility, DC, fulfillment center, or logistics center.

business_concepts.name: Warehouse Receiving
business_concepts.description: Warehouse Receiving is the inbound logistics process of accepting deliveries from suppliers or internal transfers, unloading vehicles, verifying quantities against shipping documents, inspecting for damage, and documenting receipt. Also known as goods receipt, inbound receiving, or receiving operations.

business_concepts.name: Putaway Operations
business_concepts.description: Putaway Operations is the warehouse process of moving received materials from receiving docks to designated storage locations using putaway strategies and updating location records. Also referred to as stock placement, storage allocation, or inventory stocking.

business_concepts.name: Picking Operations
business_concepts.description: Picking Operations is the warehouse process of retrieving materials from storage locations based on pick lists generated from sales orders or production requirements, using various strategies like wave picking, batch picking, or zone picking. Also known as order picking, stock retrieval, or material withdrawal.

business_concepts.name: Warehouse Slotting
business_concepts.description: Warehouse Slotting is the strategic process of assigning inventory to optimal storage locations based on product velocity, size, weight, and picking frequency to minimize travel distance and maximize efficiency. Also referred to as location optimization, slot optimization, or warehouse layout optimization.

business_concepts.name: Inventory Accuracy Management
business_concepts.description: Inventory Accuracy Management is the continuous process of maintaining precise inventory records through cycle counting, physical inventories, and transaction controls to ensure system quantities match physical quantities. Also known as inventory control, stock accuracy management, or inventory integrity maintenance.

name: Department
description: A Department is an organizational unit within the company that groups employees by function such as Production, Quality, Maintenance, Engineering, Finance, or Administration with defined responsibilities, reporting structure, and budget allocation. Also referred to as functional unit, organizational division, business unit, or organizational segment.

business_concepts.name: Budget Management
business_concepts.description: Budget Management is the financial planning and control process of allocating funds to departments, tracking actual spending against budgets, analyzing variances, and making adjustments to stay within financial targets. Also known as departmental budgeting, budget control, or expense management.

business_concepts.name: Department Performance Review
business_concepts.description: Department Performance Review is the periodic assessment of departmental KPIs, achievements against goals, resource utilization, and improvement initiatives to evaluate effectiveness and guide management decisions. Also referred to as departmental review, functional assessment, or unit performance evaluation.

business_concepts.name: Resource Allocation
business_concepts.description: Resource Allocation is the management process of assigning employees, equipment, budget, and other resources to departments based on workload, priorities, and strategic objectives to optimize organizational effectiveness. Also known as resource planning, capacity allocation, or workforce distribution.

business_concepts.name: Cross-Functional Coordination
business_concepts.description: Cross-Functional Coordination is the collaboration process where different departments work together on shared objectives, projects, or problem-solving through meetings, communication channels, and joint initiatives. Also referred to as interdepartmental collaboration, functional integration, or organizational coordination.

name: Supplier
description: A Supplier is an external business organization or individual that provides raw materials, components, finished goods, or services to the company under commercial agreements. Also referred to as vendor, supply partner, material supplier, service provider, contractor, or third-party supplier.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Onboarding
business_concepts.description: Supplier Onboarding is the end-to-end process of enrolling a new supplier into the company's procurement system, starting from initial registration through final approval to transact business. Also known as vendor onboarding, supplier enrollment, or supplier setup.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Qualification
business_concepts.description: Supplier Qualification is a comprehensive assessment process that evaluates whether a potential supplier meets the company's requirements for quality capability, technical expertise, production capacity, financial stability, and regulatory compliance before being approved to supply materials or services. Also called supplier approval, vendor qualification, or supplier certification.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Verification
business_concepts.description: Supplier Verification is the due diligence process of validating a supplier's credentials, business legitimacy, financial stability, and compliance with legal and ethical standards through background checks, reference verification, and document validation. Also known as supplier validation, vendor verification, or due diligence.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Performance Management
business_concepts.description: Supplier Performance Management is the ongoing measurement, tracking, and analysis of supplier performance against key metrics such as on-time delivery percentage, quality defect rates, responsiveness, and cost competitiveness to drive continuous improvement. Also referred to as vendor performance tracking, supplier evaluation, or supplier scorecard management.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Audit
business_concepts.description: Supplier Audit is a systematic examination of a supplier's facilities, quality management systems, manufacturing processes, and compliance practices to verify conformance to standards and ensure capability to meet requirements. Also known as vendor audit, quality audit, or on-site assessment.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Payment Processing
business_concepts.description: Supplier Payment Processing is the accounts payable workflow that matches supplier invoices against purchase orders and receipts, approves invoices for payment, schedules payment according to terms, and executes payment. Also called vendor payment, invoice processing, or payment disbursement.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Development
business_concepts.description: Supplier Development is a collaborative program where the buying company works with suppliers to improve their capabilities, quality performance, delivery reliability, or cost competitiveness through training, technical assistance, and process improvement initiatives. Also referred to as vendor improvement or supplier capability building.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Relationship Management
business_concepts.description: Supplier Relationship Management is the strategic approach to developing and maintaining productive, mutually beneficial relationships with key suppliers through regular communication, performance reviews, collaborative planning, and joint innovation. Also known as vendor relationship management or strategic supplier engagement.

name: Customer
description: A Customer is an external individual or organization that purchases products or services from the company under commercial terms, representing the demand side of business transactions. Also referred to as client, buyer, account, purchaser, consumer, patron, or end user.

business_concepts.name: Customer Acquisition
business_concepts.description: Customer Acquisition is the process of attracting potential buyers, converting them into paying customers, and onboarding them into the company's customer base through marketing campaigns, sales efforts, and account setup. Also known as client acquisition, new customer onboarding, or customer enrollment.

business_concepts.name: Lead Management
business_concepts.description: Lead Management is the systematic process of capturing, tracking, qualifying, nurturing, and converting sales leads through the sales pipeline until they become opportunities and eventually closed deals. Also referred to as prospect management, opportunity management, or sales pipeline management.

business_concepts.name: Quote Generation
business_concepts.description: Quote Generation is the process of creating formal price proposals for customers that specify products, quantities, unit prices, terms and conditions, delivery timelines, and total costs. Also known as quotation creation, proposal generation, or pricing proposal.

business_concepts.name: Order Taking
business_concepts.description: Order Taking is the process of receiving, validating, and recording customer purchase commitments into sales orders that specify what products will be delivered, in what quantities, by when, at what price, and under what terms. Also called order entry, order capture, or sales order creation.

business_concepts.name: Order Fulfillment
business_concepts.description: Order Fulfillment is the complete process of satisfying a customer's sales order from receipt through delivery, including inventory allocation, production scheduling, warehouse picking and packing, shipment arrangement, and delivery confirmation. Also known as fulfillment execution or order completion.

business_concepts.name: Customer Service
business_concepts.description: Customer Service is the support provided to customers before, during, and after purchase to address inquiries, resolve issues, handle complaints, and ensure customer satisfaction through service tickets, help desk, and support interactions. Also referred to as customer support or customer care.

business_concepts.name: Complaint Management
business_concepts.description: Complaint Management is the structured process of receiving, investigating, resolving, and tracking customer complaints about product quality, service issues, or delivery problems to restore customer satisfaction and prevent recurrence. Also known as grievance management or issue resolution.

business_concepts.name: Customer Invoicing
business_concepts.description: Customer Invoicing is the process of generating and sending bills to customers for products delivered or services rendered, specifying amounts due, payment terms, and payment methods. Also known as billing, invoice generation, or accounts receivable invoicing.

business_concepts.name: Payment Collection
business_concepts.description: Payment Collection is the accounts receivable process of receiving, applying, and recording customer payments against outstanding invoices to reduce receivables and complete the order-to-cash cycle. Also referred to as payment receipt, cash collection, or revenue collection.

business_concepts.name: Customer Retention
business_concepts.description: Customer Retention is the ongoing effort to maintain existing customer relationships, prevent customer churn, and increase customer lifetime value through satisfaction programs, loyalty initiatives, and relationship management. Also known as retention management or customer loyalty management.

name: Material
description: A Material is a physical item used in production or operations, including raw materials, components, sub-assemblies, consumables, or supplies that are purchased, stored, and consumed in manufacturing processes. Also referred to as item, part, component, SKU, stock keeping unit, inventory item, or material stock.

business_concepts.name: Material Procurement
business_concepts.description: Material Procurement is the process of sourcing, ordering, and purchasing materials from suppliers through purchase requisitions, RFQs, purchase orders, and supplier negotiations to ensure availability for production. Also known as material purchasing, material sourcing, or procurement process.

business_concepts.name: Material Receipt
business_concepts.description: Material Receipt is the warehouse process of accepting incoming materials from suppliers, verifying quantities against purchase orders, documenting receipt, and updating inventory records. Also known as goods receipt, receiving process, or inbound receiving.

business_concepts.name: Material Inspection
business_concepts.description: Material Inspection is the quality control process of examining incoming materials to verify they meet specifications for dimensions, appearance, functionality, and material properties before accepting them into inventory. Also called incoming inspection, receipt inspection, or quality check.

business_concepts.name: Material Storage
business_concepts.description: Material Storage is the warehouse operation of placing received materials into designated storage locations, maintaining proper storage conditions, organizing inventory, and ensuring materials are preserved until needed. Also known as warehousing, inventory storage, or material stocking.

business_concepts.name: Material Issue
business_concepts.description: Material Issue is the warehouse process of picking materials from inventory and delivering them to production lines or work orders based on BOM requirements and production schedules. Also referred to as material picking, stock issue, or material withdrawal.

business_concepts.name: Material Planning
business_concepts.description: Material Planning is the MRP process of calculating material requirements based on production schedules, sales forecasts, BOMs, current inventory, and lead times to determine what materials need to be ordered and when. Also known as MRP, material requirements planning, or demand planning.

business_concepts.name: Inventory Replenishment
business_concepts.description: Inventory Replenishment is the process of reordering materials when stock levels fall below reorder points to maintain adequate inventory for production continuity while minimizing excess stock. Also called stock replenishment, reordering, or inventory restocking.

business_concepts.name: Material Traceability
business_concepts.description: Material Traceability is the system of tracking materials through lot numbers, batch numbers, or serial numbers to enable forward traceability (where did it go) and backward traceability (where did it come from) for quality investigations and recalls. Also referred to as lot tracking, batch tracking, or genealogy tracking.

name: Product
description: A Product is a finished good or sellable item that is manufactured, assembled, or distributed by the company and sold to customers. Also referred to as finished good, end product, saleable item, manufactured item, or final product.

business_concepts.name: Product Development
business_concepts.description: Product Development is the engineering process of designing, prototyping, testing, and launching new products from concept through production release, including design verification, validation, and manufacturing handoff. Also known as new product introduction, product engineering, or NPD.

business_concepts.name: Product Costing
business_concepts.description: Product Costing is the accounting process of calculating the total cost to manufacture a product by summing material costs, labor costs, and overhead allocations to determine standard cost, profitability, and pricing. Also called cost estimation, cost accounting, or product cost analysis.

business_concepts.name: Product Pricing
business_concepts.description: Product Pricing is the commercial process of determining selling prices for products based on costs, market conditions, competitive positioning, and profit objectives through pricing strategies and discount structures. Also known as price setting, pricing strategy, or price management.

business_concepts.name: Product Quality Control
business_concepts.description: Product Quality Control is the inspection and testing process to verify finished products meet specifications, functionality requirements, and quality standards before release to customers. Also referred to as final inspection, product testing, or quality assurance.

business_concepts.name: Product Packaging
business_concepts.description: Product Packaging is the process of protecting and preparing finished products for shipment by placing them in appropriate containers, boxes, or protective materials with labels, documentation, and shipping marks. Also called packing, boxing, or product preparation.

business_concepts.name: Product Recall
business_concepts.description: Product Recall is the process of retrieving products from customers due to safety issues, quality defects, or regulatory non-compliance, including customer notification, logistics coordination, and regulatory reporting. Also known as market withdrawal or product retrieval.

name: Bill of Materials
description: A Bill of Materials is a hierarchical list defining all materials, components, and sub-assemblies required to manufacture one unit of a product including quantities, relationships, and assembly sequence. Also referred to as BOM, product structure, recipe, parts list, or material list.

business_concepts.name: BOM Creation
business_concepts.description: BOM Creation is the engineering process of defining product structure by specifying all required materials, their quantities per assembly, parent-child relationships, effectivity dates, and engineering notes. Also known as BOM development, product structure definition, or parts list creation.

business_concepts.name: BOM Maintenance
business_concepts.description: BOM Maintenance is the ongoing engineering change management process of updating BOMs when designs change, materials are substituted, or quantities are revised, maintaining version control and effectivity dates. Also referred to as BOM revision, engineering change implementation, or BOM update.

business_concepts.name: BOM Explosion
business_concepts.description: BOM Explosion is the MRP calculation process of expanding BOMs to determine all materials needed across multiple levels (parent to child to grandchild) for a given production quantity. Also known as material requirements explosion, BOM breakdown, or multi-level BOM expansion.

business_concepts.name: BOM Costing
business_concepts.description: BOM Costing is the accounting process of calculating total material cost for a product by summing the costs of all BOM components multiplied by their required quantities to determine standard product cost. Also referred to as product cost roll-up, BOM cost calculation, or material cost estimation.

name: Employee
description: An Employee is an individual hired by the company to perform work in exchange for compensation, including full-time, part-time, or contract workers across all functions and locations. Also referred to as worker, staff member, personnel, team member, associate, or labor.

business_concepts.name: Employee Hiring
business_concepts.description: Employee Hiring is the recruitment process of sourcing candidates, conducting interviews, making job offers, completing background checks, and onboarding new employees into the organization. Also known as recruitment, talent acquisition, or employee onboarding.

business_concepts.name: Attendance Tracking
business_concepts.description: Attendance Tracking is the time and attendance process of recording when employees clock in and out, tracking hours worked, breaks, and absences to support payroll processing and labor management. Also called time tracking, time clock management, or attendance recording.

business_concepts.name: Leave Management
business_concepts.description: Leave Management is the process of handling employee requests for time off including vacation, sick leave, personal days, and unpaid leave through approval workflows, balance tracking, and schedule coordination. Also known as time-off management, absence management, or PTO administration.

business_concepts.name: Performance Review
business_concepts.description: Performance Review is the periodic evaluation process where managers assess employee performance against goals and competencies, provide feedback, set development plans, and make compensation or promotion recommendations. Also called performance appraisal, performance evaluation, or annual review.

business_concepts.name: Training Administration
business_concepts.description: Training Administration is the process of identifying training needs, scheduling training programs, enrolling employees, tracking completion, and recording certifications to develop employee skills and ensure compliance. Also known as employee development, training management, or learning administration.

business_concepts.name: Payroll Processing
business_concepts.description: Payroll Processing is the compensation process of calculating employee wages, withholding taxes and deductions, generating paychecks, and distributing payments on scheduled pay dates. Also referred to as payroll execution, wage payment, or compensation processing.

business_concepts.name: Employee Termination
business_concepts.description: Employee Termination is the offboarding process of ending an employment relationship through resignation, layoff, or dismissal, including final pay calculation, benefit termination, access revocation, and exit documentation. Also known as employee separation, offboarding, or exit process.

name: Production Line
description: A Production Line is a sequence of workstations, machines, and processes arranged to manufacture products through progressive assembly or transformation steps with defined cycle times and throughput capacity. Also referred to as manufacturing line, assembly line, production cell, or fabrication line.

business_concepts.name: Line Setup
business_concepts.description: Line Setup is the changeover process of configuring a production line from one product to another including tool changes, equipment adjustments, material staging, and first article verification. Also known as changeover, setup operation, or production line configuration.

business_concepts.name: Line Balancing
business_concepts.description: Line Balancing is the industrial engineering process of distributing work evenly across workstations to minimize idle time, eliminate bottlenecks, and maximize throughput at the pace of the slowest operation. Also referred to as workload balancing, takt time optimization, or capacity balancing.

business_concepts.name: Line Monitoring
business_concepts.description: Line Monitoring is the real-time tracking process of observing production line performance including cycle times, output rates, quality metrics, downtime events, and operator efficiency to identify and resolve issues promptly. Also known as production monitoring, line surveillance, or real-time tracking.

business_concepts.name: Continuous Improvement
business_concepts.description: Continuous Improvement is the ongoing effort to analyze production line performance, identify waste, implement lean manufacturing principles, and make incremental improvements to increase efficiency, quality, and safety. Also referred to as kaizen, lean manufacturing, or process optimization.

name: Machine
description: A Machine is a piece of production equipment or manufacturing tool used to perform specific operations such as cutting, forming, assembling, or testing in the manufacturing process. Also referred to as equipment, production equipment, manufacturing machinery, or production asset.

business_concepts.name: Machine Operation
business_concepts.description: Machine Operation is the production process of running equipment according to work instructions, loading materials, setting parameters, monitoring operation, and producing output while ensuring safety and quality standards. Also known as equipment operation, machine running, or production execution.

business_concepts.name: Machine Maintenance
business_concepts.description: Machine Maintenance is the systematic care and servicing of equipment through preventive maintenance schedules, corrective repairs, parts replacement, and condition monitoring to ensure reliability and extend asset life. Also referred to as equipment maintenance, machine servicing, or asset care.

business_concepts.name: Machine Utilization Tracking
business_concepts.description: Machine Utilization Tracking is the measurement process of recording equipment run time, idle time, setup time, and downtime to calculate utilization percentages and identify capacity improvement opportunities. Also known as equipment utilization monitoring, asset tracking, or capacity measurement.

business_concepts.name: Machine Calibration
business_concepts.description: Machine Calibration is the process of adjusting and verifying equipment settings and parameters against standards to ensure consistent, accurate production within specifications. Also referred to as equipment calibration, machine setup verification, or parameter validation.

name: Lead
description: A Lead is a potential customer or business contact who has expressed interest in the company's products or services but has not yet been qualified as a sales opportunity. Also referred to as prospect, potential customer, sales lead, or inquirer.

business_concepts.name: Lead Capture
business_concepts.description: Lead Capture is the marketing process of collecting contact information and interest details from potential customers through web forms, trade shows, referrals, campaigns, or inbound inquiries. Also known as lead generation, prospect identification, or contact acquisition.

business_concepts.name: Lead Qualification
business_concepts.description: Lead Qualification is the sales process of evaluating leads against criteria such as budget, authority, need, and timeline to determine if they are worth pursuing as sales opportunities. Also referred to as lead scoring, prospect qualification, or opportunity assessment.

business_concepts.name: Lead Nurturing
business_concepts.description: Lead Nurturing is the marketing process of maintaining engagement with leads through email campaigns, content sharing, follow-up calls, and educational materials to build relationships until they are ready to buy. Also known as prospect development, lead cultivation, or relationship building.

business_concepts.name: Lead Assignment
business_concepts.description: Lead Assignment is the distribution process of routing qualified leads to appropriate sales representatives based on territory, product specialization, or workload balancing for follow-up and conversion. Also referred to as lead routing, territory assignment, or sales rep allocation.

name: Opportunity
description: An Opportunity is a qualified sales prospect with identified needs, budget, decision-making authority, and timeline representing potential revenue that progresses through defined sales stages toward closure. Also referred to as sales opportunity, deal, sales prospect, or potential sale.

business_concepts.name: Opportunity Creation
business_concepts.description: Opportunity Creation is the sales process of converting qualified leads into formal sales opportunities by documenting customer needs, estimated value, probability, expected close date, and competitive situation. Also known as deal creation, opportunity setup, or sales pipeline entry.

business_concepts.name: Opportunity Progression
business_concepts.description: Opportunity Progression is the sales management process of advancing opportunities through defined sales stages (prospect, qualify, propose, negotiate, close) based on completion of stage-specific activities and milestones. Also referred to as pipeline advancement, deal progression, or stage movement.

business_concepts.name: Sales Forecasting
business_concepts.description: Sales Forecasting is the predictive process of estimating future revenue by analyzing opportunities in the pipeline, their probabilities, and expected close dates to project sales performance and resource needs. Also known as revenue forecasting, pipeline forecasting, or sales projection.

business_concepts.name: Win/Loss Analysis
business_concepts.description: Win/Loss Analysis is the post-mortem review process of examining closed opportunities to understand why deals were won or lost, identifying patterns, strengths, weaknesses, and improvement actions. Also referred to as deal analysis, outcome review, or competitive analysis.

name: Quote
description: A Quote is a formal price proposal provided to a customer specifying products, quantities, unit prices, terms and conditions, delivery timelines, and total costs in response to a customer inquiry or RFQ. Also referred to as quotation, price proposal, bid, or sales estimate.

business_concepts.name: Quote Preparation
business_concepts.description: Quote Preparation is the sales process of gathering customer requirements, selecting products, calculating pricing including discounts, defining terms, and compiling a formal quote document for customer review. Also known as quotation creation, bid preparation, or proposal development.

business_concepts.name: Quote Approval
business_concepts.description: Quote Approval is the authorization workflow where quotes exceeding approval thresholds are routed to management for review and approval based on margin, discount levels, or contract terms before being sent to customers. Also referred to as pricing approval, quote authorization, or management review.

business_concepts.name: Quote Negotiation
business_concepts.description: Quote Negotiation is the interactive process of discussing and revising quote terms with customers including price adjustments, payment terms, delivery schedules, and specifications until mutual agreement is reached. Also known as price negotiation, terms discussion, or deal structuring.

business_concepts.name: Quote Conversion
business_concepts.description: Quote Conversion is the order management process of transforming an accepted quote into a sales order that triggers production planning, inventory allocation, and fulfillment activities. Also referred to as quote-to-order conversion, order booking, or deal closure.

name: Sales Territory
description: A Sales Territory is a geographic region or defined set of customer accounts assigned to a sales representative for coverage, relationship management, and revenue accountability. Also referred to as sales region, sales area, territory assignment, or account portfolio.

business_concepts.name: Territory Planning
business_concepts.description: Territory Planning is the sales management process of designing territory boundaries, balancing workload, aligning with company strategy, and assigning territories to sales reps to optimize coverage and maximize revenue potential. Also known as territory design, sales area allocation, or geographic planning.

business_concepts.name: Territory Performance Tracking
business_concepts.description: Territory Performance Tracking is the measurement process of monitoring sales results, activity levels, pipeline health, and goal achievement by territory to evaluate effectiveness and identify coaching needs. Also referred to as territory analysis, regional performance monitoring, or sales metrics tracking.

business_concepts.name: Territory Realignment
business_concepts.description: Territory Realignment is the periodic process of adjusting territory boundaries, reassigning accounts, or redistributing sales representatives based on market changes, growth patterns, or workload imbalances. Also known as territory rebalancing, account redistribution, or coverage optimization.

name: Campaign
description: A Campaign is an organized marketing initiative designed to promote products, generate leads, build brand awareness, or drive sales through coordinated activities across multiple channels over a defined time period. Also referred to as marketing campaign, promotional campaign, or marketing program.

business_concepts.name: Campaign Planning
business_concepts.description: Campaign Planning is the marketing process of defining campaign objectives, target audience, messaging, channels, budget, timeline, and success metrics before execution. Also known as campaign design, marketing planning, or promotional strategy.

business_concepts.name: Campaign Execution
business_concepts.description: Campaign Execution is the implementation process of launching marketing activities including email blasts, advertising, events, content distribution, and social media according to the campaign plan. Also referred to as campaign launch, marketing activation, or promotional deployment.

business_concepts.name: Campaign Performance Measurement
business_concepts.description: Campaign Performance Measurement is the analytics process of tracking campaign metrics such as reach, engagement, lead generation, conversion rates, and ROI to evaluate effectiveness and inform future campaigns. Also known as campaign analysis, marketing analytics, or performance assessment.

business_concepts.name: Lead Generation from Campaign
business_concepts.description: Lead Generation from Campaign is the conversion process of capturing contact information and interest signals from campaign respondents and routing them to sales for follow-up. Also referred to as prospect capture, inquiry management, or lead acquisition.

name: Service Ticket
description: A Service Ticket is a record documenting a customer support request, issue, or inquiry that tracks the problem description, priority, assigned representative, resolution actions, and closure status. Also referred to as support ticket, case, service request, or help desk ticket.

business_concepts.name: Ticket Creation
business_concepts.description: Ticket Creation is the customer service process of logging a new support request by capturing customer information, issue description, priority level, and routing to the appropriate support queue or agent. Also known as case opening, request logging, or issue documentation.

business_concepts.name: Ticket Assignment
business_concepts.description: Ticket Assignment is the work distribution process of routing service tickets to appropriate support representatives based on skill sets, product expertise, availability, and workload balancing. Also referred to as case routing, agent assignment, or work allocation.

business_concepts.name: Ticket Resolution
business_concepts.description: Ticket Resolution is the problem-solving process where support agents investigate issues, provide solutions, communicate with customers, and implement fixes until the customer's problem is resolved satisfactorily. Also known as issue resolution, problem solving, or case closure.

business_concepts.name: SLA Monitoring
business_concepts.description: SLA Monitoring is the service level management process of tracking ticket response times and resolution times against contracted service level agreements and escalating at-risk tickets to prevent SLA breaches. Also referred to as service level tracking, SLA compliance monitoring, or response time management.

business_concepts.name: Ticket Escalation
business_concepts.description: Ticket Escalation is the prioritization process of elevating unresolved or high-severity tickets to senior support staff or management when initial resolution attempts fail or SLAs are at risk. Also known as case escalation, issue elevation, or management involvement.

name: Warranty Claim
description: A Warranty Claim is a customer request for repair or replacement of a defective product still covered under manufacturer or extended warranty terms. Also referred to as warranty request, warranty service, or warranty fulfillment.

business_concepts.name: Warranty Validation
business_concepts.description: Warranty Validation is the verification process of checking whether a product is still within warranty coverage by examining purchase date, serial number, warranty terms, and prior claim history before approving service. Also known as coverage verification, warranty check, or eligibility confirmation.

business_concepts.name: Warranty Claim Processing
business_concepts.description: Warranty Claim Processing is the service workflow of receiving warranty requests, validating coverage, approving claims, authorizing repair or replacement, tracking service completion, and updating warranty records. Also referred to as claim fulfillment, warranty service execution, or claim administration.

business_concepts.name: Warranty Cost Tracking
business_concepts.description: Warranty Cost Tracking is the financial process of recording all warranty-related expenses including parts, labor, shipping, and overhead to analyze warranty costs by product, supplier, or defect type for quality improvement and cost management. Also known as warranty expense monitoring, cost analysis, or warranty financial tracking.

name: Return Merchandise Authorization
description: A Return Merchandise Authorization (RMA) is approval granted to customers to return products for credit, replacement, or repair with specific instructions on return shipping and disposition. Also referred to as RMA, return authorization, or product return approval.

business_concepts.name: RMA Issuance
business_concepts.description: RMA Issuance is the customer service process of authorizing product returns by assigning an RMA number, providing return instructions, specifying eligible items, and setting expectations for credit or replacement. Also known as return authorization, RMA approval, or return permission.

business_concepts.name: Return Receipt
business_concepts.description: Return Receipt is the warehouse process of receiving returned products, verifying RMA authorization, inspecting condition, documenting receipt, and routing items for disposition evaluation. Also referred to as returned goods receiving, RMA receipt, or return acceptance.

business_concepts.name: Return Disposition
business_concepts.description: Return Disposition is the decision-making process of determining what to do with returned products including restocking for resale, refurbishing, returning to supplier, or scrapping based on condition and economics. Also known as return evaluation, disposition ruling, or return processing.

business_concepts.name: Customer Credit Processing
business_concepts.description: Customer Credit Processing is the accounting workflow of issuing refunds or account credits to customers for returned products after validating RMA completion and disposition decisions. Also referred to as refund processing, credit issuance, or return settlement.

name: Service Contract
description: A Service Contract is an agreement between company and customer defining extended support services, maintenance programs, response times, and fees beyond standard warranty coverage. Also referred to as support agreement, maintenance contract, or service level agreement.

business_concepts.name: Contract Enrollment
business_concepts.description: Contract Enrollment is the sales process of selling service contracts to customers, defining coverage terms, collecting fees, setting up contract records, and activating service entitlements. Also known as service contract sales, agreement setup, or coverage activation.

business_concepts.name: Contract Renewal
business_concepts.description: Contract Renewal is the account management process of contacting customers before contract expiration, proposing renewal terms, negotiating pricing, and processing contract extensions to maintain continuous coverage. Also referred to as contract extension, agreement renewal, or service continuation.

business_concepts.name: Contract Entitlement Verification
business_concepts.description: Contract Entitlement Verification is the service validation process of checking whether customers are covered under active service contracts before providing support to ensure proper billing and service authorization. Also known as coverage check, entitlement validation, or service eligibility verification.

name: Training Program
description: A Training Program is a structured educational course or curriculum designed to develop employee skills, knowledge, certifications, or competencies required for job performance or career development. Also referred to as training course, learning program, development program, or educational curriculum.

business_concepts.name: Training Needs Assessment
business_concepts.description: Training Needs Assessment is the analysis process of identifying skill gaps, compliance requirements, and development opportunities by evaluating job requirements, employee competencies, and business objectives. Also known as skills gap analysis, training requirements identification, or learning needs evaluation.

business_concepts.name: Training Scheduling
business_concepts.description: Training Scheduling is the logistics process of planning training sessions, booking instructors, reserving facilities, enrolling participants, and communicating schedules to ensure organized training delivery. Also referred to as course scheduling, training calendar management, or session planning.

business_concepts.name: Training Delivery
business_concepts.description: Training Delivery is the instruction process of conducting training sessions through classroom instruction, online courses, on-the-job training, or workshops to transfer knowledge and skills to employees. Also known as training execution, course instruction, or educational delivery.

business_concepts.name: Training Effectiveness Evaluation
business_concepts.description: Training Effectiveness Evaluation is the assessment process of measuring training outcomes through tests, performance observations, feedback surveys, and skill application to determine if training objectives were achieved. Also referred to as training assessment, learning evaluation, or training ROI measurement.

name: Performance Review
description: A Performance Review is a periodic formal evaluation of an employee's job performance, goal achievement, competencies, and development needs conducted by their manager. Also referred to as performance appraisal, performance evaluation, annual review, or performance assessment.

business_concepts.name: Goal Setting
business_concepts.description: Goal Setting is the performance management process where managers and employees collaborate to establish specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound objectives aligned with organizational goals. Also known as objective setting, target definition, or KPI establishment.

business_concepts.name: Performance Assessment
business_concepts.description: Performance Assessment is the evaluation process where managers review employee achievements, behaviors, and competencies against established goals and job expectations through observations, metrics, and 360-degree feedback. Also referred to as performance evaluation, rating process, or competency assessment.

business_concepts.name: Feedback Delivery
business_concepts.description: Feedback Delivery is the communication process of discussing performance review results with employees, recognizing achievements, addressing development areas, and creating improvement plans in constructive one-on-one meetings. Also known as review discussion, performance conversation, or feedback session.

business_concepts.name: Performance Improvement Planning
business_concepts.description: Performance Improvement Planning is the development process of creating action plans for employees not meeting expectations, defining specific improvement goals, support resources, timelines, and consequences. Also referred to as PIP creation, corrective action planning, or performance management planning.

name: Payroll
description: Payroll is the compensation system that calculates and disburses employee wages based on hours worked, salaries, bonuses, commissions, deductions, and taxes. Also referred to as compensation processing, wage payment, or employee payment system.

business_concepts.name: Payroll Calculation
business_concepts.description: Payroll Calculation is the accounting process of computing gross pay from time records and salary rates, calculating required deductions for taxes, benefits, and garnishments, and determining net pay amounts. Also known as wage calculation, pay computation, or compensation processing.

business_concepts.name: Payroll Execution
business_concepts.description: Payroll Execution is the disbursement process of generating paychecks or direct deposits, distributing pay stubs, transmitting tax withholdings to authorities, and recording payroll transactions in the general ledger. Also referred to as payroll processing, payment distribution, or paycheck generation.

business_concepts.name: Payroll Tax Filing
business_concepts.description: Payroll Tax Filing is the compliance process of preparing and submitting required payroll tax reports and payments to federal, state, and local tax authorities including quarterly returns and annual reconciliations. Also known as tax compliance, payroll tax reporting, or withholding remittance.

business_concepts.name: Year-End Payroll Processing
business_concepts.description: Year-End Payroll Processing is the annual closing process of reconciling payroll for the tax year, generating W-2 forms for employees, filing required tax documents, and preparing for new year payroll setup. Also referred to as payroll year-end close, W-2 preparation, or annual payroll finalization.

name: Shift Schedule
description: A Shift Schedule is a planned work roster that defines which employees work which shifts on specific dates to ensure adequate staffing coverage while balancing employee preferences and labor regulations. Also referred to as work schedule, staff roster, shift plan, or workforce schedule.

business_concepts.name: Schedule Creation
business_concepts.description: Schedule Creation is the workforce planning process of building employee work schedules considering staffing requirements, employee availability, skills needed, shift patterns, and labor rules. Also known as roster planning, shift planning, or schedule building.

business_concepts.name: Shift Assignment
business_concepts.description: Shift Assignment is the scheduling process of assigning specific employees to shifts based on qualifications, seniority, preferences, and operational needs while ensuring fair distribution of undesirable shifts. Also referred to as staff assignment, shift allocation, or employee rostering.

business_concepts.name: Schedule Adjustment
business_concepts.description: Schedule Adjustment is the dynamic process of modifying published schedules to accommodate employee requests, absences, workload changes, or unexpected events through shift swaps or coverage arrangements. Also known as schedule changes, shift modifications, or roster updates.

business_concepts.name: Schedule Communication
business_concepts.description: Schedule Communication is the notification process of publishing and distributing work schedules to employees through bulletin boards, mobile apps, or employee portals providing adequate advance notice and confirming acknowledgment. Also referred to as schedule distribution, roster publication, or shift notification.

name: Purchase Order
description: A Purchase Order is a formal procurement document issued to a supplier authorizing them to deliver specified materials or services at agreed prices and terms, representing a legally binding commitment to purchase. Also referred to as PO, procurement order, or purchase commitment.

business_concepts.name: Purchase Order Creation
business_concepts.description: Purchase Order Creation is the procurement process of generating a purchase order from approved requisitions or MRP planned orders, selecting suppliers, specifying materials and quantities, negotiating prices, and issuing the PO to the supplier. Also known as PO generation, order placement, or purchase order issuance.

business_concepts.name: Purchase Order Approval
business_concepts.description: Purchase Order Approval is the workflow process of routing purchase orders through authorization hierarchies based on dollar thresholds, budget availability, and approval policies before release to suppliers. Also referred to as PO authorization, procurement approval, or purchase approval workflow.

business_concepts.name: Purchase Order Receipt
business_concepts.description: Purchase Order Receipt is the warehouse process of receiving materials against a purchase order, verifying quantities, documenting receipt with packing slips, and updating the PO status and inventory records. Also called goods receipt, PO receiving, or inbound receipt.

business_concepts.name: Purchase Order Closure
business_concepts.description: Purchase Order Closure is the final step of completing a purchase order after all materials are received, invoices are matched, payments are made, and the PO is administratively closed in the system. Also known as PO finalization, order completion, or PO closeout.

business_concepts.name: Three-Way Matching
business_concepts.description: Three-Way Matching is the accounts payable control process of comparing the purchase order, material receipt, and supplier invoice to verify quantities and prices match before approving the invoice for payment. Also referred to as invoice matching, PO-receipt-invoice reconciliation, or match validation.

name: Sales Order
description: A Sales Order is a confirmed customer purchase commitment that authorizes the company to manufacture or deliver specified products at agreed prices and delivery dates, representing revenue to be recognized. Also referred to as SO, customer order, or sales transaction.

business_concepts.name: Sales Order Entry
business_concepts.description: Sales Order Entry is the order management process of capturing customer orders, validating product availability, confirming pricing, setting delivery dates, and creating the sales order record in the system. Also known as order booking, order capture, or order creation.

business_concepts.name: Credit Check
business_concepts.description: Credit Check is the financial control process of verifying a customer's credit limit and payment history before accepting a sales order to manage credit risk and prevent bad debt. Also referred to as credit approval, credit validation, or creditworthiness verification.

business_concepts.name: Order Promising
business_concepts.description: Order Promising is the supply chain process of determining realistic delivery dates for sales orders based on inventory availability, production capacity, and material lead times using ATP (available-to-promise) logic. Also known as delivery date confirmation, ATP calculation, or promise date determination.

business_concepts.name: Order Allocation
business_concepts.description: Order Allocation is the inventory management process of reserving inventory for specific sales orders to prevent overselling and ensure fulfillment priority based on order importance, delivery dates, and allocation rules. Also referred to as inventory reservation, stock allocation, or order commit.

business_concepts.name: Order Shipping
business_concepts.description: Order Shipping is the fulfillment process of picking, packing, and loading sales order items onto carriers for delivery to customers, including generating shipping documents, tracking numbers, and shipment confirmation. Also known as order dispatch, shipment execution, or delivery processing.

business_concepts.name: Sales Invoicing
business_concepts.description: Sales Invoicing is the billing process of generating customer invoices for delivered products or completed services, calculating amounts due including taxes and freight, and submitting invoices for payment. Also referred to as customer billing, invoice generation, or AR invoicing.

name: Inventory
description: Inventory is the stock of materials, work-in-progress, and finished goods held by the company at various locations for production consumption or customer sale, representing a significant asset on the balance sheet. Also referred to as stock, on-hand inventory, available inventory, warehouse stock, or material stock.

business_concepts.name: Inventory Receipt
business_concepts.description: Inventory Receipt is the warehouse transaction that increases inventory quantities when materials are received from suppliers, production output is completed, or transfers are received from other locations. Also known as stock receipt, inventory addition, or goods inward.

business_concepts.name: Inventory Issue
business_concepts.description: Inventory Issue is the warehouse transaction that decreases inventory quantities when materials are consumed by production, products are shipped to customers, or items are transferred to other locations. Also referred to as stock issue, inventory withdrawal, or material consumption.

business_concepts.name: Inventory Transfer
business_concepts.description: Inventory Transfer is the warehouse operation of moving inventory from one location to another, such as between warehouses, from bulk to picking locations, or between storage zones, updating location records. Also known as stock transfer, inventory movement, or location transfer.

business_concepts.name: Inventory Adjustment
business_concepts.description: Inventory Adjustment is the process of correcting inventory records to match physical counts when discrepancies are found through cycle counts, physical inventories, or investigation of errors, shrinkage, or damage. Also referred to as stock correction, inventory correction, or quantity adjustment.

business_concepts.name: Inventory Valuation
business_concepts.description: Inventory Valuation is the accounting process of calculating the total financial value of inventory using costing methods (FIFO, LIFO, weighted average, standard cost) for balance sheet reporting and cost of goods sold calculations. Also known as stock valuation, inventory accounting, or inventory cost calculation.

business_concepts.name: Inventory Reconciliation
business_concepts.description: Inventory Reconciliation is the process of comparing physical inventory counts against system records, investigating variances, making necessary adjustments, and ensuring inventory accuracy for financial and operational integrity. Also referred to as inventory verification, stock reconciliation, or inventory audit.

business_concepts.name: Inventory Optimization
business_concepts.description: Inventory Optimization is the analysis and adjustment of inventory policies including safety stock levels, reorder points, order quantities, and stocking strategies to balance service levels with inventory carrying costs. Also known as inventory planning, stock optimization, or inventory policy management.

name: Purchase Requisition
description: A Purchase Requisition is an internal request for procurement of materials or services that initiates the buying process, subject to approval workflow before conversion to purchase orders. Also referred to as PR, procurement request, or buy request.

business_concepts.name: Requisition Creation
business_concepts.description: Requisition Creation is the procurement initiation process where employees request materials or services by specifying items needed, quantities, justification, budget codes, and delivery requirements. Also known as purchase request, PR generation, or requisition entry.

business_concepts.name: Requisition Approval
business_concepts.description: Requisition Approval is the authorization workflow where purchase requisitions are routed through management hierarchies for budget verification and approval before proceeding to sourcing and PO creation. Also referred to as PR authorization, procurement approval, or requisition review.

business_concepts.name: Requisition to RFQ Conversion
business_concepts.description: Requisition to RFQ Conversion is the sourcing process of transforming approved requisitions into requests for quotation sent to multiple suppliers to obtain competitive pricing before selecting a supplier. Also known as competitive bidding, quote solicitation, or supplier selection.

business_concepts.name: Requisition to PO Conversion
business_concepts.description: Requisition to PO Conversion is the procurement process of transforming approved requisitions into purchase orders either directly (for preferred suppliers) or after RFQ evaluation and supplier selection. Also referred to as PO generation from requisition, order placement, or procurement execution.

name: Cycle Count
description: A Cycle Count is a periodic physical inventory verification program where warehouse locations are counted on rotating schedules to maintain inventory accuracy without requiring full facility shutdowns. Also referred to as perpetual inventory counting, continuous counting, or partial inventory count.

business_concepts.name: Cycle Count Scheduling
business_concepts.description: Cycle Count Scheduling is the planning process of determining which locations or items to count, how frequently to count them (based on ABC classification), assigning count dates, and generating count sheets. Also known as count planning, counting schedule creation, or count assignment.

business_concepts.name: Physical Counting
business_concepts.description: Physical Counting is the warehouse activity of counting inventory quantities at designated locations, recording counts on sheets or devices, and verifying counts through blind counts or re-counts. Also referred to as inventory counting, physical verification, or stock counting.

business_concepts.name: Count Variance Analysis
business_concepts.description: Count Variance Analysis is the investigation process of comparing physical counts against system records, calculating discrepancies, determining root causes of variances, and deciding whether to adjust inventory records. Also known as variance investigation, discrepancy analysis, or count reconciliation.

business_concepts.name: Inventory Adjustment from Count
business_concepts.description: Inventory Adjustment from Count is the corrective action of updating system inventory quantities to match physical counts when variances exceed tolerance thresholds, recording reasons and creating audit trails. Also referred to as cycle count adjustment, inventory correction, or count-based adjustment.

name: General Ledger Account
description: A General Ledger Account is a financial account in the chart of accounts that categorizes and summarizes business transactions by type such as assets, liabilities, equity, revenue, or expenses for financial reporting. Also referred to as GL account, ledger account, financial account, or account code.

business_concepts.name: Journal Entry Posting
business_concepts.description: Journal Entry Posting is the accounting process of recording financial transactions as debits and credits to GL accounts, maintaining the double-entry accounting principle where total debits equal total credits. Also known as GL posting, transaction recording, or accounting entry.

business_concepts.name: Account Reconciliation
business_concepts.description: Account Reconciliation is the control process of comparing GL account balances against supporting documentation (bank statements, subledgers, invoices) to verify accuracy, identify discrepancies, and make corrective adjustments. Also referred to as GL reconciliation, balance verification, or account verification.

business_concepts.name: Financial Close
business_concepts.description: Financial Close is the period-end accounting process of completing all transactions for the period, reconciling accounts, making adjusting entries, calculating balances, and producing financial statements. Also known as month-end close, period close, or accounting close.

business_concepts.name: Budget vs Actual Analysis
business_concepts.description: Budget vs Actual Analysis is the management reporting process of comparing actual GL account activity against budgeted amounts to identify variances, understand performance, and take corrective actions. Also referred to as variance analysis, budget monitoring, or financial performance review.

name: Journal Entry
description: A Journal Entry is a double-entry accounting transaction that records debits and credits to GL accounts documenting business events such as sales, purchases, accruals, or adjustments. Also referred to as accounting entry, GL transaction, or financial posting.

business_concepts.name: Manual Journal Entry Creation
business_concepts.description: Manual Journal Entry Creation is the accounting process of preparing journal entries for transactions not automatically generated by operational systems, such as accruals, adjustments, reclassifications, or corrections. Also known as manual posting, accounting adjustment, or JE preparation.

business_concepts.name: Automated Posting from Operations
business_concepts.description: Automated Posting from Operations is the system integration where operational transactions (sales orders, production completion, inventory movements) automatically generate journal entries based on posting rules without manual accountant intervention. Also referred to as auto-posting, system-generated entries, or integrated accounting.

business_concepts.name: Journal Entry Approval
business_concepts.description: Journal Entry Approval is the control workflow where journal entries above certain thresholds or of specific types are routed through accounting management for review and authorization before posting to the general ledger. Also known as JE authorization, posting approval, or accounting review.

business_concepts.name: Journal Entry Reversal
business_concepts.description: Journal Entry Reversal is the correction process of creating offsetting entries to cancel previously posted journal entries due to errors, period adjustments, or temporary accruals that need unwinding. Also referred to as JE reversal, entry correction, or posting cancellation.

name: Cost Center
description: A Cost Center is an organizational unit (department, production line, project) used for cost tracking and management reporting that incurs expenses but does not directly generate revenue. Also referred to as responsibility center, expense center, or cost allocation unit.

business_concepts.name: Cost Center Budget Allocation
business_concepts.description: Cost Center Budget Allocation is the planning process of assigning annual or periodic expense budgets to cost centers based on historical spending, planned activities, and strategic priorities. Also known as budget distribution, cost center funding, or expense budget assignment.

business_concepts.name: Cost Center Expense Tracking
business_concepts.description: Cost Center Expense Tracking is the accounting process of recording all expenses (labor, materials, overhead) to appropriate cost centers enabling visibility into where money is being spent and departmental cost management. Also referred to as cost allocation, expense assignment, or departmental accounting.

business_concepts.name: Cost Center Performance Analysis
business_concepts.description: Cost Center Performance Analysis is the management review process of comparing actual costs against budgets by cost center, analyzing variances, identifying cost drivers, and implementing cost control measures. Also known as cost variance analysis, departmental review, or budget performance monitoring.

name: Fiscal Period
description: A Fiscal Period is a time interval (typically monthly or quarterly) within a fiscal year used for financial reporting, transaction posting, and performance measurement, with open/closed status controlling transaction entry. Also referred to as accounting period, reporting period, financial period, or GL period.

business_concepts.name: Period Opening
business_concepts.description: Period Opening is the accounting process of starting a new fiscal period by carrying forward ending balances from the previous period as beginning balances and enabling transaction posting for the new period. Also known as period activation, new period start, or period initialization.

business_concepts.name: Period Closing
business_concepts.description: Period Closing is the accounting process of completing a fiscal period by preventing further transaction posting, finalizing balances, generating financial statements, and carrying balances forward to the next period. Also referred to as period lockdown, period finalization, or period end.

business_concepts.name: Period Adjustment
business_concepts.description: Period Adjustment is the accounting process of making corrective entries in prior periods (if still open) or current periods to fix errors, record accruals, or reclassify transactions for accurate financial reporting. Also known as adjusting entry, period correction, or accounting adjustment.

name: Budget
description: A Budget is a financial plan defining expected revenues and expenses by GL account, cost center, and time period used for planning, authorization, and performance measurement. Also referred to as financial plan, operating budget, expense budget, or spending plan.

business_concepts.name: Budget Planning
business_concepts.description: Budget Planning is the annual process of forecasting revenues and expenses for the upcoming fiscal year considering strategic objectives, historical trends, market conditions, and resource requirements. Also known as budgeting, financial planning, or budget development.

business_concepts.name: Budget Approval
business_concepts.description: Budget Approval is the authorization workflow where proposed budgets are reviewed by management and executive leadership, negotiated, adjusted, and formally approved before implementation. Also referred to as budget authorization, financial plan approval, or budget finalization.

business_concepts.name: Budget Monitoring
business_concepts.description: Budget Monitoring is the ongoing control process of tracking actual spending and revenue against approved budgets, identifying variances, forecasting year-end performance, and taking corrective actions when needed. Also known as budget tracking, variance monitoring, or budget control.

business_concepts.name: Budget Revision
business_concepts.description: Budget Revision is the adjustment process of modifying approved budgets during the fiscal year due to changing conditions, new initiatives, or reallocation of resources, subject to approval workflows. Also referred to as budget amendment, budget adjustment, or reforecasting.

name: Inventory Snapshot
description: An Inventory Snapshot is a consolidated, point-in-time view of inventory quantities combining data from ERP (aggregate) and WMS (bin-level) systems to provide a unified inventory position. Also referred to as consolidated inventory view, inventory position, or unified stock view.

business_concepts.name: Snapshot Generation
business_concepts.description: Snapshot Generation is the data aggregation process of combining inventory records from ERP and WMS systems at specific time intervals to create a comprehensive view of inventory on-hand, allocated, and available quantities. Also known as inventory consolidation, data aggregation, or unified view creation.

business_concepts.name: Variance Detection
business_concepts.description: Variance Detection is the comparison process of identifying discrepancies between ERP and WMS inventory quantities by analyzing snapshot data and flagging differences that exceed tolerance thresholds. Also referred to as discrepancy identification, mismatch detection, or inventory variance analysis.

business_concepts.name: Reconciliation Reporting
business_concepts.description: Reconciliation Reporting is the analysis process of producing reports showing inventory variances by material, location, and variance magnitude to guide investigation and resolution efforts. Also known as variance reporting, inventory reconciliation reports, or discrepancy analysis.

name: Sync Queue Entry
description: A Sync Queue Entry is a transactional record in the synchronization queue that represents an inventory movement requiring synchronization between ERP and WMS systems with retry logic for failed syncs. Also referred to as sync transaction, queue message, or synchronization record.

business_concepts.name: Queue Processing
business_concepts.description: Queue Processing is the automated workflow that continuously processes synchronization queue entries by reading transactions, applying updates to target systems, updating sync status, and retrying failed transactions. Also known as sync execution, message processing, or transaction synchronization.

business_concepts.name: Retry Management
business_concepts.description: Retry Management is the error handling process that automatically reattempts failed synchronization transactions based on retry limits and backoff strategies before flagging items for manual intervention. Also referred to as failure recovery, retry logic, or error handling.

business_concepts.name: Sync Error Resolution
business_concepts.description: Sync Error Resolution is the troubleshooting process of investigating permanently failed sync transactions, correcting root causes (data issues, system connectivity), and manually reprocessing or adjusting records. Also known as error correction, sync failure remediation, or manual intervention.

name: Work Order
description: A Work Order is a production job that instructs the manufacturing floor to produce a specified quantity of a product following a defined routing and BOM, tracking actual consumption and output. Also referred to as production order, manufacturing order, shop order, job order, or production job.

business_concepts.name: Work Order Creation
business_concepts.description: Work Order Creation is the production planning process of generating work orders from sales orders, MRP planned orders, or forecasts, specifying what to make, how much, when, and which resources to use. Also known as production order generation, job creation, or manufacturing order release.

business_concepts.name: Work Order Scheduling
business_concepts.description: Work Order Scheduling is the production planning process of assigning work orders to specific production lines, machines, and time slots based on capacity, priorities, setup times, and due dates to create an executable production schedule. Also referred to as production scheduling, job sequencing, or shop floor scheduling.

business_concepts.name: Material Issue to Production
business_concepts.description: Material Issue to Production is the warehouse process of picking and delivering materials required by work orders from inventory to production lines based on BOM requirements and production schedules. Also known as material kitting, component staging, or material allocation to jobs.

business_concepts.name: Production Execution
business_concepts.description: Production Execution is the shop floor process of operators performing manufacturing operations according to work instructions, consuming materials, recording labor time, and producing output as specified in the work order. Also referred to as job execution, manufacturing operations, or production run.

business_concepts.name: Quality Inspection
business_concepts.description: Quality Inspection is the quality control process of examining products at various stages of production against specifications to verify conformance, identify defects, and determine accept/reject decisions. Also known as in-process inspection, quality check, or product verification.

business_concepts.name: Work Order Completion
business_concepts.description: Work Order Completion is the final step of closing a work order after production is finished, actual quantities and costs are recorded, finished goods are moved to inventory, and variances are analyzed. Also referred to as job closure, production completion, or work order finalization.

business_concepts.name: Production Reporting
business_concepts.description: Production Reporting is the process of capturing actual production data including quantities produced, materials consumed, labor hours, machine time, scrap, and downtime to provide visibility into shop floor performance. Also known as shop floor data collection, production tracking, or manufacturing reporting.

name: Routing
description: A Routing is a sequence of manufacturing operations defining how a product is made, specifying the work centers, operation steps, setup times, run times, and labor requirements for production. Also referred to as process routing, manufacturing routing, production sequence, or process plan.

business_concepts.name: Routing Development
business_concepts.description: Routing Development is the industrial engineering process of designing the manufacturing process sequence by defining operations, selecting work centers, establishing standard times, and documenting work instructions. Also known as process planning, routing creation, or manufacturing process design.

business_concepts.name: Time Study
business_concepts.description: Time Study is the industrial engineering method of observing and measuring actual operation times to establish standard setup times and run times per unit used in routing definitions and capacity planning. Also referred to as time standards setting, work measurement, or time and motion study.

business_concepts.name: Routing Optimization
business_concepts.description: Routing Optimization is the continuous improvement process of analyzing current routings, identifying bottlenecks, reducing setup times, eliminating non-value steps, and improving efficiency to reduce manufacturing cost and lead time. Also known as process improvement, lean manufacturing, or cycle time reduction.

name: Work Center
description: A Work Center is a production resource (machine, cell, assembly line, or workstation) where manufacturing operations are performed with defined capacity, capabilities, and cost rates. Also referred to as production resource, machine center, manufacturing cell, or production station.

business_concepts.name: Work Center Capacity Planning
business_concepts.description: Work Center Capacity Planning is the analysis process of calculating available capacity by work center considering shifts, efficiency, planned downtime, and comparing against load from scheduled work orders to identify constraints. Also known as capacity analysis, load planning, or resource capacity management.

business_concepts.name: Work Center Loading
business_concepts.description: Work Center Loading is the scheduling process of assigning work orders to work centers and time periods, visualizing workload distribution, and balancing load across resources to prevent overloading and underutilization. Also referred to as capacity loading, resource assignment, or workload balancing.

business_concepts.name: Work Center Performance Tracking
business_concepts.description: Work Center Performance Tracking is the measurement process of monitoring work center efficiency, utilization, throughput, and quality metrics to identify underperforming resources and improvement opportunities. Also known as resource monitoring, performance measurement, or efficiency tracking.

name: Production Batch
