description: A Production Batch is a quantity of products manufactured together under the same conditions, assigned a batch or lot number for traceability, quality control, and inventory management. Also referred to as manufacturing lot, production lot, batch, or lot number.

business_concepts.name: Batch Creation
business_concepts.description: Batch Creation is the production process of assigning batch numbers to groups of products manufactured together, recording production date, operators, materials consumed, and process parameters for traceability. Also known as lot number assignment, batch numbering, or batch documentation.

business_concepts.name: Batch Traceability
business_concepts.description: Batch Traceability is the tracking system that links production batches to consumed material lots enabling forward traceability (which customers received this batch) and backward traceability (which materials went into this batch) for quality investigations and recalls. Also referred to as lot genealogy, batch tracking, or production traceability.

business_concepts.name: Batch Quality Testing
business_concepts.description: Batch Quality Testing is the quality control process of sampling and testing products from each production batch to verify conformance to specifications before releasing the batch for shipment or inventory. Also known as lot testing, batch sampling, or batch release testing.

business_concepts.name: Batch Hold and Release
business_concepts.description: Batch Hold and Release is the quality management process of placing production batches on hold pending quality test results, investigation of defects, or regulatory approval, then releasing for use when cleared. Also referred to as batch quarantine, lot hold, or batch approval.

name: Downtime Event
description: A Downtime Event is an unplanned stoppage of production equipment or lines with documented downtime type, duration, root cause, and resolution actions. Also referred to as machine stoppage, equipment downtime, production interruption, or availability loss.

business_concepts.name: Downtime Recording
business_concepts.description: Downtime Recording is the data capture process where operators or automated systems log equipment stoppages including start time, end time, downtime reason code, and problem description. Also known as downtime logging, stoppage documentation, or downtime data collection.

business_concepts.name: Downtime Classification
business_concepts.description: Downtime Classification is the categorization process of assigning downtime events to reason codes (mechanical failure, no material, no operator, changeover, maintenance) for accurate analysis and improvement targeting. Also referred to as reason coding, downtime categorization, or loss classification.

business_concepts.name: Downtime Analysis
business_concepts.description: Downtime Analysis is the continuous improvement process of analyzing downtime patterns by equipment, reason, shift, or product to identify major loss contributors and prioritize improvement initiatives. Also known as downtime trending, pareto analysis, or loss analysis.

business_concepts.name: Downtime Reduction Projects
business_concepts.description: Downtime Reduction Projects are targeted improvement initiatives using root cause analysis, SMED (Single-Minute Exchange of Die), TPM (Total Productive Maintenance), or other methods to eliminate or reduce specific downtime causes. Also referred to as reliability improvement, availability projects, or loss elimination.

name: Warehouse Location
description: A Warehouse Location is a specific storage position within a warehouse identified by aisle, bay, level, and bin coordinates where inventory is physically stored and tracked. Also referred to as storage bin, warehouse bin, storage location, or inventory location.

business_concepts.name: Location Setup
business_concepts.description: Location Setup is the warehouse configuration process of defining storage locations with capacity constraints, storage types (bulk, picking, staging), temperature zones, and handling requirements. Also known as bin configuration, location creation, or warehouse layout setup.

business_concepts.name: Location Assignment
business_concepts.description: Location Assignment is the putaway process of determining optimal storage locations for received materials based on location characteristics, product attributes, and slotting strategies. Also referred to as bin assignment, storage allocation, or location determination.

business_concepts.name: Location Capacity Management
business_concepts.description: Location Capacity Management is the space utilization process of tracking occupied versus available capacity in each location to prevent overfilling and optimize warehouse space usage. Also known as space management, capacity tracking, or location utilization.

business_concepts.name: Location Accuracy Verification
business_concepts.description: Location Accuracy Verification is the cycle counting process of physically verifying that materials recorded in specific locations actually exist there in correct quantities and conditions. Also referred to as bin verification, location audit, or accuracy check.

name: Wave
description: A Wave is a group of picking tasks consolidated together for efficient batch processing, optimizing picker routing, workload balancing, and shipment consolidation. Also referred to as pick wave, order wave, or batch picking group.

business_concepts.name: Wave Planning
business_concepts.description: Wave Planning is the order fulfillment process of grouping sales orders into waves based on carrier schedules, order priorities, picker capacity, and shipping deadlines. Also known as wave creation, order batching, or wave configuration.

business_concepts.name: Wave Release
business_concepts.description: Wave Release is the execution trigger that generates pick lists, allocates inventory, creates pick tasks, and dispatches pickers to fulfill orders in the wave. Also referred to as wave launch, pick release, or wave execution.

business_concepts.name: Wave Monitoring
business_concepts.description: Wave Monitoring is the real-time tracking process of observing wave progress including picks completed, items staged, orders shipped, and performance against time targets. Also known as wave tracking, fulfillment monitoring, or progress tracking.

business_concepts.name: Wave Completion
business_concepts.description: Wave Completion is the closing process of finalizing all picks in a wave, resolving short picks or exceptions, updating inventory, and confirming wave readiness for packing and shipping. Also referred to as wave closure, wave finalization, or fulfillment completion.

name: Pick Task
description: A Pick Task is an instruction to retrieve a specific material from a storage location in a defined quantity for order fulfillment or production supply. Also referred to as pick order, picking instruction, or retrieval task.

business_concepts.name: Pick Task Generation
business_concepts.description: Pick Task Generation is the automated process of creating picking instructions from sales orders or production requirements, determining pick locations, quantities, and picker assignments. Also known as pick list creation, task generation, or pick assignment.

business_concepts.name: Pick Task Execution
business_concepts.description: Pick Task Execution is the warehouse operation where pickers follow pick lists to retrieve items from storage locations, scan confirmations, and transport items to staging or packing areas. Also referred to as order picking, pick completion, or retrieval execution.

business_concepts.name: Pick Task Optimization
business_concepts.description: Pick Task Optimization is the warehouse engineering process of sequencing pick tasks to minimize travel distance, reduce picker fatigue, and maximize throughput using zone picking, batch picking, or optimal routing. Also known as pick path optimization, route planning, or pick sequencing.

business_concepts.name: Short Pick Resolution
business_concepts.description: Short Pick Resolution is the exception handling process of addressing situations where inventory cannot be picked as planned due to stock-outs, damage, or location errors, including inventory lookup and alternative sourcing. Also referred to as pick shortage handling, stock-out resolution, or pick exception management.

name: Packing Container
description: A Packing Container is a box, carton, pallet, or tote used to consolidate and protect picked items for shipment to customers with tracking through container identifiers. Also referred to as shipping container, package, carton, or shipping unit.

business_concepts.name: Container Packing
business_concepts.description: Container Packing is the warehouse process of placing picked items into appropriate containers with protective materials, optimizing space utilization, and ensuring safe transit. Also known as order packing, package preparation, or carton packing.

business_concepts.name: Container Labeling
business_concepts.description: Container Labeling is the shipping documentation process of applying shipping labels, tracking barcodes, destination addresses, and handling instructions to packed containers. Also referred to as package labeling, label application, or shipping mark assignment.

business_concepts.name: Container Weighing
business_concepts.description: Container Weighing is the verification process of measuring packed container weight to validate against expected weight, determine shipping charges, and ensure carrier compliance. Also known as package weighing, weight verification, or dimensional weight calculation.

business_concepts.name: Container Manifesting
business_concepts.description: Container Manifesting is the shipment documentation process of grouping containers into carrier manifests, generating bills of lading, and transmitting shipment details to carriers for pickup. Also referred to as shipment manifesting, carrier notification, or load documentation.

name: Replenishment
description: Replenishment is the warehouse task of moving inventory from bulk storage to forward picking locations when stock in picking areas falls below minimum levels. Also referred to as stock replenishment, pick face replenishment, or inventory replenishment.

business_concepts.name: Replenishment Planning
business_concepts.description: Replenishment Planning is the inventory management process of calculating when and how much inventory to move to picking locations based on usage rates, minimum/maximum levels, and space constraints. Also known as replenishment calculation, min-max planning, or stock level management.

business_concepts.name: Replenishment Execution
business_concepts.description: Replenishment Execution is the warehouse task of physically moving materials from reserve storage to picking locations based on replenishment instructions, updating location records upon completion. Also referred to as stock movement, location refill, or pick face replenishment.

business_concepts.name: Automatic Replenishment
business_concepts.description: Automatic Replenishment is the system-triggered process where replenishment tasks are generated automatically when picking location quantities fall below reorder points without manual intervention. Also known as auto-replenishment, automated stock refill, or system-triggered replenishment.

name: Shipment
description: A Shipment is a consolidated delivery of products being transported from the company to customers or between company locations, tracked through transportation carriers with delivery documentation. Also referred to as delivery, freight shipment, outbound load, transportation consignment, or carrier shipment.

business_concepts.name: Shipment Planning
business_concepts.description: Shipment Planning is the logistics process of consolidating sales orders into shipments, selecting carriers, determining routing, scheduling pickup times, and optimizing loads for cost efficiency and delivery requirements. Also known as load planning, freight planning, or delivery planning.

business_concepts.name: Carrier Selection
business_concepts.description: Carrier Selection is the transportation management process of choosing the appropriate freight carrier and service level based on cost, transit time, destination, product requirements, and carrier performance. Also referred to as carrier assignment, transport mode selection, or freight carrier choice.

business_concepts.name: Shipment Tracking
business_concepts.description: Shipment Tracking is the monitoring process of tracking in-transit shipments through carrier systems, GPS, or RFID to provide real-time location visibility, estimated delivery times, and proactive exception management. Also known as delivery tracking, freight visibility, or in-transit monitoring.

business_concepts.name: Proof of Delivery
business_concepts.description: Proof of Delivery is the documentation process of obtaining customer signatures, delivery timestamps, condition notes, and photos confirming successful delivery and providing evidence for dispute resolution. Also referred to as POD, delivery confirmation, or signed receipt.

business_concepts.name: Freight Payment
business_concepts.description: Freight Payment is the accounts payable process of receiving, auditing, and paying carrier invoices for transportation services after validating charges against contracted rates and shipment details. Also known as freight billing, carrier payment, or transportation payment processing.

name: Carrier
description: A Carrier is a transportation service provider (trucking company, courier, freight forwarder, or logistics provider) contracted to transport shipments between locations. Also referred to as freight carrier, transportation provider, shipping company, or logistics partner.

business_concepts.name: Carrier Qualification
business_concepts.description: Carrier Qualification is the procurement process of evaluating and approving transportation providers based on safety records, insurance coverage, service capabilities, geographic coverage, and pricing before awarding business. Also known as carrier vetting, carrier onboarding, or carrier approval.

business_concepts.name: Carrier Rate Negotiation
business_concepts.description: Carrier Rate Negotiation is the contract process of negotiating transportation rates, fuel surcharges, accessorial fees, service levels, and contract terms with carriers to optimize transportation costs. Also referred to as freight rate negotiation, carrier contracting, or rate agreement.

business_concepts.name: Carrier Performance Monitoring
business_concepts.description: Carrier Performance Monitoring is the ongoing measurement of carrier metrics including on-time delivery percentage, damage rates, claims frequency, and customer satisfaction to drive accountability and continuous improvement. Also known as carrier scorecard, transportation KPI tracking, or carrier evaluation.

business_concepts.name: Carrier Capacity Management
business_concepts.description: Carrier Capacity Management is the relationship process of maintaining adequate carrier capacity during peak seasons, communicating volume forecasts, and managing capacity constraints through carrier partnerships. Also referred to as capacity planning, carrier relationship management, or transportation capacity.

name: Route
description: A Route is a planned transportation path from origin to destination including waypoints, mileage, transit time, and handling instructions for shipment delivery. Also referred to as delivery route, transportation path, shipping route, or freight route.

business_concepts.name: Route Planning
business_concepts.description: Route Planning is the logistics optimization process of determining optimal transportation paths considering distance, transit time, fuel costs, toll roads, and delivery time windows. Also known as route optimization, path planning, or delivery route design.

business_concepts.name: Route Execution
business_concepts.description: Route Execution is the transportation process where carriers follow planned routes to make deliveries, with real-time updates on progress, delays, and deviations from plan. Also referred to as route running, delivery execution, or route completion.

business_concepts.name: Multi-Stop Route Optimization
business_concepts.description: Multi-Stop Route Optimization is the complex planning process of sequencing multiple delivery stops on a single route to minimize total distance, respect time windows, and maximize driver efficiency. Also known as route sequencing, stop optimization, or vehicle routing.

name: Freight Rate
description: A Freight Rate is the price charged by carriers for transportation services, varying by weight, distance, service level, and special handling requirements. Also referred to as transportation rate, shipping cost, carrier rate, or freight charge.

business_concepts.name: Rate Calculation
business_concepts.description: Rate Calculation is the pricing process of computing transportation costs based on shipment characteristics (weight, dimensions, commodity class), distance, selected carrier, and service level using rate tables or quoting systems. Also known as freight costing, rate determination, or shipping cost calculation.

business_concepts.name: Rate Shopping
business_concepts.description: Rate Shopping is the carrier selection process of comparing freight rates from multiple carriers for the same shipment to identify the most cost-effective option meeting service requirements. Also referred to as carrier comparison, rate comparison, or freight quote analysis.

business_concepts.name: Rate Audit
business_concepts.description: Rate Audit is the accounts payable control process of verifying that carrier invoices match contracted rates, validating weight and distance calculations, and disputing overcharges before payment. Also known as freight audit, invoice validation, or billing verification.

name: Delivery Appointment
description: A Delivery Appointment is a scheduled time window when a shipment will arrive at the destination, coordinated between carrier, shipper, and receiver to ensure receiving dock availability. Also referred to as delivery window, scheduled delivery, or appointment slot.

business_concepts.name: Appointment Scheduling
business_concepts.description: Appointment Scheduling is the coordination process of arranging delivery time windows with customers, reserving receiving dock capacity, and communicating schedules to carriers for on-time delivery. Also known as delivery scheduling, dock scheduling, or appointment booking.

business_concepts.name: Appointment Confirmation
business_concepts.description: Appointment Confirmation is the communication process of verifying delivery appointments with all parties, sending reminders, and updating schedules when changes occur. Also referred to as delivery confirmation, schedule verification, or appointment acknowledgment.

business_concepts.name: Appointment Compliance Tracking
business_concepts.description: Appointment Compliance Tracking is the performance measurement process of monitoring whether deliveries arrive within scheduled windows and analyzing root causes of missed appointments for improvement. Also known as on-time delivery tracking, appointment adherence, or schedule performance.

name: Equipment
description: Equipment refers to production machinery, manufacturing tools, material handling devices, and facility systems used in operations that require maintenance, monitoring, and performance tracking. Also referred to as machine, asset, production equipment, manufacturing machinery, or physical asset.

business_concepts.name: Equipment Installation
business_concepts.description: Equipment Installation is the process of setting up new machinery or equipment including site preparation, installation, calibration, safety certification, operator training, and production qualification. Also known as equipment commissioning, machine setup, or asset deployment.

business_concepts.name: Preventive Maintenance
business_concepts.description: Preventive Maintenance is the scheduled maintenance program of performing routine service tasks (lubrication, inspections, parts replacement) on equipment at planned intervals to prevent failures and extend asset life. Also referred to as PM, scheduled maintenance, or planned maintenance.

business_concepts.name: Corrective Maintenance
business_concepts.description: Corrective Maintenance is the reactive maintenance process of repairing equipment after breakdowns or failures occur, including troubleshooting, parts replacement, testing, and return to service. Also known as breakdown maintenance, repair work, or reactive maintenance.

business_concepts.name: Equipment Calibration
business_concepts.description: Equipment Calibration is the process of adjusting and verifying the accuracy of measuring and testing equipment against known standards to ensure measurement reliability and regulatory compliance. Also referred to as calibration verification, equipment standardization, or accuracy check.

business_concepts.name: Equipment Performance Monitoring
business_concepts.description: Equipment Performance Monitoring is the continuous measurement of equipment metrics including Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE), availability, performance efficiency, quality rate, and MTBF to drive reliability improvements. Also referred to as machine monitoring, OEE tracking, or asset performance management.

name: Maintenance Work Order
description: A Maintenance Work Order is a task assignment for maintenance activities on equipment including description, priority, assigned technician, required parts, and completion documentation. Also referred to as maintenance order, work request, repair order, or maintenance ticket.

business_concepts.name: Work Order Creation
business_concepts.description: Work Order Creation is the maintenance planning process of generating work orders from PM schedules, equipment breakdowns, or condition monitoring alerts, specifying tasks, resources, and timing. Also known as work order generation, maintenance request, or job creation.

business_concepts.name: Work Order Prioritization
business_concepts.description: Work Order Prioritization is the scheduling process of ranking maintenance work orders by urgency considering production impact, safety risks, regulatory requirements, and resource availability. Also referred to as priority assignment, job ranking, or criticality assessment.

business_concepts.name: Work Order Assignment
business_concepts.description: Work Order Assignment is the resource allocation process of assigning maintenance work to qualified technicians based on skills, workload, availability, and geographic location. Also known as technician assignment, job dispatch, or work allocation.

business_concepts.name: Work Order Execution
business_concepts.description: Work Order Execution is the maintenance activity where technicians perform required tasks, document labor hours, record parts used, note findings, and update equipment status. Also referred to as maintenance execution, job completion, or repair work.

business_concepts.name: Work Order Closure
business_concepts.description: Work Order Closure is the completion process of verifying all tasks are done, equipment is returned to service, costs are captured, and work orders are administratively closed in the system. Also known as job closure, work completion, or order finalization.

name: Maintenance Schedule
description: A Maintenance Schedule is a time-based or meter-based plan defining when preventive maintenance tasks should be performed on equipment to prevent failures. Also referred to as PM schedule, maintenance plan, service schedule, or maintenance program.

business_concepts.name: Schedule Development
business_concepts.description: Schedule Development is the planning process of creating maintenance schedules based on equipment manufacturer recommendations, failure history, criticality analysis, and regulatory requirements. Also known as PM planning, schedule creation, or maintenance program design.

business_concepts.name: Schedule Execution
business_concepts.description: Schedule Execution is the automated process of generating maintenance work orders when scheduled maintenance becomes due based on calendar dates or equipment runtime meters. Also referred to as PM generation, scheduled task creation, or automatic work order generation.

business_concepts.name: Schedule Compliance Tracking
business_concepts.description: Schedule Compliance Tracking is the measurement process of monitoring whether preventive maintenance tasks are completed on time and calculating PM compliance percentages by equipment or facility. Also known as PM compliance, schedule adherence, or maintenance KPI tracking.

business_concepts.name: Schedule Optimization
business_concepts.description: Schedule Optimization is the continuous improvement process of adjusting PM frequencies, task content, or intervals based on equipment reliability data, failure analysis, and cost-benefit evaluation. Also referred to as PM optimization, schedule tuning, or maintenance improvement.

name: Spare Part
description: A Spare Part is an inventory item stocked specifically for equipment maintenance and repair, including replacement components, consumables, and repair materials. Also referred to as maintenance part, repair part, service part, or MRO inventory.

business_concepts.name: Spare Parts Planning
business_concepts.description: Spare Parts Planning is the inventory management process of determining which parts to stock, in what quantities, at which locations based on equipment installed base, failure rates, lead times, and criticality. Also known as spare parts inventory planning, MRO planning, or parts optimization.

business_concepts.name: Parts Issue to Maintenance
business_concepts.description: Parts Issue to Maintenance is the warehouse process of picking spare parts required for maintenance work orders and delivering them to technicians or job sites with proper documentation and inventory updates. Also referred to as parts picking, maintenance parts withdrawal, or parts allocation.

business_concepts.name: Parts Return Processing
business_concepts.description: Parts Return Processing is the warehouse workflow of receiving unused parts back into inventory from completed maintenance jobs, inspecting condition, updating quantities, and processing warranty returns to suppliers. Also known as parts putback, unused parts return, or parts restocking.

business_concepts.name: Parts Usage Analysis
business_concepts.description: Parts Usage Analysis is the reporting process of analyzing spare parts consumption patterns, identifying high-usage items, slow-moving inventory, and obsolete stock to optimize inventory levels. Also referred to as parts consumption analysis, inventory turnover analysis, or usage tracking.

name: Equipment Failure
description: An Equipment Failure is an unplanned breakdown or malfunction that stops equipment from operating, requiring corrective maintenance to restore functionality. Also referred to as breakdown, equipment fault, machine failure, or malfunction.

business_concepts.name: Failure Reporting
business_concepts.description: Failure Reporting is the documentation process of recording equipment breakdowns including failure symptoms, time of occurrence, operating conditions, and production impact to trigger maintenance response. Also known as breakdown reporting, fault logging, or failure documentation.

business_concepts.name: Failure Root Cause Analysis
business_concepts.description: Failure Root Cause Analysis is the investigation process using methods like FMEA, fault tree analysis, or fishbone diagrams to identify underlying causes of equipment failures rather than just addressing symptoms. Also referred to as RCA, failure investigation, or cause determination.

business_concepts.name: Failure Mode Analysis
business_concepts.description: Failure Mode Analysis is the reliability engineering process of analyzing how equipment can fail, the effects of failures, criticality ratings, and prevention strategies to improve design and maintenance. Also known as FMEA, failure effects analysis, or reliability analysis.

business_concepts.name: Failure Cost Tracking
business_concepts.description: Failure Cost Tracking is the accounting process of capturing all costs associated with equipment failures including lost production, emergency repairs, overtime labor, and expedited parts to justify reliability improvements. Also referred to as downtime costing, failure cost analysis, or breakdown cost tracking.

name: Sensor
description: A Sensor is an IoT device that monitors and measures physical parameters such as temperature, pressure, vibration, speed, or position on equipment and processes, transmitting data for analysis and control. Also referred to as IoT sensor, monitoring device, measurement device, telemetry sensor, or connected device.

business_concepts.name: Sensor Installation
business_concepts.description: Sensor Installation is the deployment process of physically mounting sensors on equipment, connecting to networks, configuring parameters, testing signals, and integrating with data collection systems. Also known as sensor deployment, IoT device setup, or instrumentation installation.

business_concepts.name: Real-Time Monitoring
business_concepts.description: Real-Time Monitoring is the continuous process of collecting sensor data, displaying current values on dashboards, comparing against thresholds, and providing instant visibility into equipment and process conditions. Also referred to as live monitoring, real-time surveillance, or continuous monitoring.

business_concepts.name: Anomaly Detection
business_concepts.description: Anomaly Detection is the analytical process of using statistical methods or machine learning to identify abnormal patterns in sensor data that may indicate equipment problems, quality issues, or process deviations requiring investigation. Also known as outlier detection, abnormal pattern recognition, or exception identification.

business_concepts.name: Predictive Maintenance Trigger
business_concepts.description: Predictive Maintenance Trigger is the condition-based maintenance process where sensor data indicating deteriorating equipment health (vibration increase, temperature rise, efficiency drop) automatically generates maintenance work orders before failures occur. Also referred to as condition-based maintenance, CBM triggering, or predictive work order creation.

business_concepts.name: Data Aggregation
business_concepts.description: Data Aggregation is the data management process of summarizing high-frequency sensor data into time-based averages, minimums, maximums, or statistical summaries to reduce storage requirements while preserving analytical value. Also known as data summarization, time-series aggregation, or data compression.

name: Sensor Reading
description: A Sensor Reading is a timestamped measurement captured by an IoT sensor representing the value of a monitored parameter at a specific moment. Also referred to as sensor data point, measurement reading, telemetry data, or sensor value.

business_concepts.name: Data Collection
business_concepts.description: Data Collection is the automated process of continuously capturing sensor measurements, timestamping readings, and transmitting data to edge devices or cloud platforms for storage and analysis. Also known as data acquisition, sensor polling, or telemetry collection.

business_concepts.name: Data Validation
business_concepts.description: Data Validation is the quality control process of checking sensor readings for plausibility, detecting out-of-range values, identifying sensor malfunctions, and flagging suspect data for investigation. Also referred to as data quality checking, reading verification, or sensor health monitoring.

business_concepts.name: Threshold Alerting
business_concepts.description: Threshold Alerting is the notification process where sensor readings exceeding configured thresholds trigger immediate alerts to operators, maintenance personnel, or automated control systems for intervention. Also known as alarm generation, threshold notification, or exception alerting.

business_concepts.name: Historical Trending
business_concepts.description: Historical Trending is the analysis process of visualizing sensor reading patterns over time to identify trends, correlations, seasonal variations, and long-term degradation for predictive insights. Also referred to as time-series analysis, trend visualization, or historical data analysis.

name: Alert Rule
description: An Alert Rule is a configured threshold or condition that triggers notifications when sensor data indicates abnormal situations requiring attention or intervention. Also referred to as alarm rule, threshold configuration, notification trigger, or alert condition.

business_concepts.name: Alert Configuration
business_concepts.description: Alert Configuration is the setup process of defining alert rules including threshold values, comparison operators, hysteresis bands, time delays, and notification recipients. Also known as alarm setup, rule configuration, or threshold definition.

business_concepts.name: Alert Triggering
business_concepts.description: Alert Triggering is the automated evaluation process where sensor readings are continuously compared against alert rules and notifications are sent when conditions are met. Also referred to as alarm activation, alert generation, or notification firing.

business_concepts.name: Alert Management
business_concepts.description: Alert Management is the operational process of receiving alerts, acknowledging notifications, investigating causes, taking corrective actions, and documenting resolutions. Also known as alarm handling, alert response, or notification management.

business_concepts.name: Alert Tuning
business_concepts.description: Alert Tuning is the optimization process of adjusting alert thresholds to reduce false alarms while ensuring critical conditions are detected, based on historical data analysis and operational feedback. Also referred to as threshold optimization, alarm refinement, or alert calibration.

name: Supplier Collaboration
description: Supplier Collaboration is the digital partnership where suppliers and buyers exchange information, coordinate activities, and work together through shared platforms to improve supply chain efficiency. Also referred to as vendor collaboration, supply chain collaboration, or supplier partnership.

business_concepts.name: Forecast Sharing
business_concepts.description: Forecast Sharing is the supply chain visibility process where buyers share demand forecasts with suppliers enabling them to plan capacity, materials, and inventory proactively. Also known as demand visibility, forecast collaboration, or planning synchronization.

business_concepts.name: Inventory Visibility
business_concepts.description: Inventory Visibility is the transparency process where suppliers can view buyer's inventory levels and consumption rates to support vendor-managed inventory or just-in-time delivery programs. Also referred to as stock visibility, inventory transparency, or VMI enablement.

business_concepts.name: Collaborative Planning
business_concepts.description: Collaborative Planning is the joint planning process where buyers and suppliers work together on capacity planning, new product introductions, and continuous improvement initiatives. Also known as supply chain planning collaboration, joint business planning, or strategic partnership.

business_concepts.name: Performance Feedback
business_concepts.description: Performance Feedback is the communication process where buyers share supplier performance scorecards, quality issues, and improvement suggestions to drive continuous enhancement of supplier capabilities. Also referred to as supplier feedback, performance review sharing, or scorecard communication.

name: Supplier Invoice
description: A Supplier Invoice submitted through the supplier portal is a digital payment request for goods delivered or services rendered with portal-based status tracking and electronic approval workflows. Also referred to as vendor invoice, electronic invoice, e-invoice, or digital billing.

business_concepts.name: Invoice Submission
business_concepts.description: Invoice Submission is the supplier self-service process of creating and submitting invoices through the portal with attachments, automatically routing to buyer's AP system for processing. Also known as e-invoicing, digital invoice submission, or portal-based invoicing.

business_concepts.name: Invoice Status Tracking
business_concepts.description: Invoice Status Tracking is the transparency feature where suppliers can view invoice processing status including received, under review, approved, scheduled for payment, or paid through the portal. Also referred to as invoice visibility, payment tracking, or status monitoring.

business_concepts.name: Invoice Dispute Resolution
business_concepts.description: Invoice Dispute Resolution is the collaborative process where buyers and suppliers communicate through the portal to resolve invoice discrepancies, pricing questions, or quantity disputes. Also known as dispute management, invoice clarification, or exception resolution.

business_concepts.name: Electronic Payment Remittance
business_concepts.description: Electronic Payment Remittance is the notification process where suppliers receive payment confirmations and remittance details through the portal when invoices are paid. Also referred to as payment notification, remittance advice, or payment confirmation.

name: Purchase Order Acknowledgment
description: A Purchase Order Acknowledgment is a supplier's confirmation of receipt and acceptance of a purchase order with committed delivery dates and any noted exceptions or changes. Also referred to as PO confirmation, order acceptance, or purchase acknowledgment.

business_concepts.name: PO Review
business_concepts.description: PO Review is the supplier process of examining newly received purchase orders through the portal to verify they can meet specifications, quantities, delivery dates, and pricing before acceptance. Also known as order review, PO evaluation, or order verification.

business_concepts.name: PO Acceptance
business_concepts.description: PO Acceptance is the supplier action of confirming receipt and commitment to fulfill a purchase order, communicating acceptance back to the buyer through the portal. Also referred to as order confirmation, PO acknowledgment, or order acceptance.

business_concepts.name: Delivery Date Commitment
business_concepts.description: Delivery Date Commitment is the supplier promise of when goods will be delivered, either confirming buyer-requested dates or proposing alternative dates based on production capacity and material availability. Also known as ship date commitment, delivery promise, or lead time confirmation.

business_concepts.name: Exception Notification
business_concepts.description: Exception Notification is the communication process where suppliers alert buyers through the portal about potential delivery delays, quantity shortages, or other order fulfillment issues requiring resolution. Also referred to as delivery alert, order exception, or fulfillment warning.

name: Advanced Ship Notice
description: An Advanced Ship Notice (ASN) is a supplier notification sent through the portal providing advance details about a shipment's contents, packaging, carrier, and expected arrival time. Also referred to as ASN, shipping notice, advance shipping notification, or delivery notification.

business_concepts.name: ASN Creation
business_concepts.description: ASN Creation is the supplier process of generating shipping notifications with detailed shipment information including items, quantities, serial numbers, packing details, and tracking numbers before dispatch. Also known as shipping notice generation, ASN preparation, or advance notification.

business_concepts.name: ASN Transmission
business_concepts.description: ASN Transmission is the electronic communication process where suppliers send advance shipping notices to buyers through the portal enabling receiving preparation and dock scheduling. Also referred to as ASN sending, shipping notice submission, or electronic notification.

business_concepts.name: Cross-Reference to PO
business_concepts.description: Cross-Reference to PO is the data linking process where ASNs reference specific purchase orders and line items enabling buyers to match incoming shipments to expected deliveries. Also known as PO matching, order reference, or shipment linkage.

business_concepts.name: Receiving Confirmation
business_concepts.description: Receiving Confirmation is the buyer feedback where receipt of goods is confirmed through the portal, allowing suppliers to track that shipments arrived and were accepted. Also referred to as delivery confirmation, receipt acknowledgment, or goods receipt notification.

name: Quality Issue
description: A Quality Issue communicated through the supplier portal is a buyer notification to suppliers about defects, non-conformances, or quality problems requiring supplier response and corrective action. Also referred to as supplier quality notification, quality alert, defect notification, or NCR to supplier.

business_concepts.name: Quality Issue Notification
business_concepts.description: Quality Issue Notification is the buyer process of alerting suppliers about quality problems through the portal including defect description, quantities affected, photos, and urgency level. Also known as defect notification, quality alert, or NCR communication.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Response
business_concepts.description: Supplier Response is the acknowledgment and action plan submitted by suppliers addressing quality issues including root cause investigation, immediate containment, and long-term corrective actions. Also referred to as corrective action response, quality response, or supplier CAPA.

business_concepts.name: 8D Problem Solving
business_concepts.description: 8D Problem Solving is the structured quality methodology used by suppliers to investigate quality issues through eight disciplines: team formation, problem description, containment, root cause, corrective actions, verification, prevention, and recognition. Also known as eight disciplines, 8D response, or structured problem solving.

business_concepts.name: Issue Closure
business_concepts.description: Issue Closure is the verification process where buyers review supplier corrective actions, confirm effectiveness, approve closure, and update supplier quality records. Also referred to as CAPA closure, quality issue resolution, or problem closure.

name: Quality Inspection
description: Quality Inspection is the examination and testing of materials, products, or processes against specifications to verify conformance, identify defects, and determine acceptance or rejection decisions. Also referred to as quality check, quality control inspection, product verification, or inspection activity.

business_concepts.name: Incoming Inspection
business_concepts.description: Incoming Inspection is the quality control process of examining materials received from suppliers before acceptance into inventory to verify they meet specifications and are free from defects. Also known as receiving inspection, goods inward inspection, or supplier quality check.

business_concepts.name: In-Process Inspection
business_concepts.description: In-Process Inspection is the quality control practice of checking products at various stages during manufacturing to detect defects early, prevent defect propagation, and ensure process control. Also referred to as in-line inspection, production inspection, or process verification.

business_concepts.name: Final Inspection
business_concepts.description: Final Inspection is the comprehensive quality check performed on finished products before shipment to verify they meet all customer requirements, specifications, and quality standards. Also known as final quality control, pre-shipment inspection, or product acceptance testing.

business_concepts.name: First Article Inspection
business_concepts.description: First Article Inspection is the detailed inspection of the first unit produced after a new setup or process change to verify the manufacturing process is capable of producing conforming products. Also referred to as FAI, first piece inspection, or setup verification.

business_concepts.name: Inspection Documentation
business_concepts.description: Inspection Documentation is the process of recording inspection results, measurements, defects found, accept/reject decisions, and inspector signatures to provide quality records and traceability. Also known as inspection reporting, quality records, or inspection data collection.

name: Non-Conformance
description: A Non-Conformance is a defect, deficiency, or deviation from specified requirements found in materials, products, or processes that fails to meet quality standards or customer expectations. Also referred to as NCR, defect, quality issue, non-conforming material, or quality defect.

business_concepts.name: NCR Creation
business_concepts.description: NCR Creation is the quality process of documenting a non-conformance by recording the defect description, affected material/product, quantity, severity, and detection details to initiate investigation and resolution. Also known as defect reporting, non-conformance logging, or quality issue documentation.

business_concepts.name: Containment Action
business_concepts.description: Containment Action is the immediate response to a non-conformance that prevents defective materials or products from being used in production or shipped to customers by segregating, holding, or quarantining affected items. Also referred to as immediate action, defect isolation, or material hold.

business_concepts.name: Root Cause Analysis
business_concepts.description: Root Cause Analysis is the systematic investigation using methods like 5-Why, Fishbone diagrams, or Fault Tree Analysis to identify the underlying causes of non-conformances rather than just addressing symptoms. Also known as RCA, cause investigation, or problem analysis.

business_concepts.name: Disposition Decision
business_concepts.description: Disposition Decision is the quality determination of what to do with non-conforming materials or products by classifying them as scrap, rework, use-as-is, return to supplier, or sort/screen based on defect severity and economics. Also referred to as material disposition, disposition ruling, or defect resolution.

business_concepts.name: CAPA Initiation
business_concepts.description: CAPA Initiation is the quality process of creating a Corrective and Preventive Action plan when non-conformances indicate systemic issues requiring permanent solutions to prevent recurrence. Also known as corrective action creation, CAPA generation, or improvement initiative.

name: Corrective Action
description: Corrective Action (CAPA) is a systematic approach to investigating problems, identifying root causes, implementing solutions, and verifying effectiveness to prevent recurrence of non-conformances and drive continuous improvement. Also referred to as CAPA, corrective and preventive action, quality improvement action, or problem resolution.

business_concepts.name: Problem Investigation
business_concepts.description: Problem Investigation is the analytical process within CAPA of gathering facts, analyzing data, interviewing personnel, and using problem-solving tools to understand what happened and why the non-conformance occurred. Also known as problem analysis, investigation phase, or root cause determination.

business_concepts.name: Corrective Action Implementation
business_concepts.description: Corrective Action Implementation is the execution phase of CAPA where permanent solutions are deployed including process changes, equipment modifications, training programs, or procedure updates to fix the identified root causes. Also referred to as solution deployment, action execution, or improvement implementation.

business_concepts.name: Effectiveness Verification
business_concepts.description: Effectiveness Verification is the follow-up process of monitoring results after corrective actions are implemented to confirm the problem is resolved, defects have not recurred, and the solution is sustainable. Also known as verification of effectiveness, solution validation, or follow-up audit.

business_concepts.name: Preventive Action
business_concepts.description: Preventive Action is the proactive component of CAPA that identifies and eliminates potential causes of non-conformances before they occur by analyzing trends, risks, and near-misses to implement preventive measures. Also referred to as risk mitigation, proactive improvement, or prevention measures.

name: Quality Audit
description: A Quality Audit is a systematic, independent examination of processes, procedures, systems, or products to verify compliance with standards, identify improvement opportunities, and assess quality system effectiveness. Also referred to as compliance audit, system audit, quality review, or quality assessment.

business_concepts.name: Audit Planning
business_concepts.description: Audit Planning is the preparation process of defining audit scope, objectives, schedule, checklist, team assignments, and notification of auditees to ensure organized and effective audit execution. Also known as audit preparation, audit scheduling, or audit scoping.

business_concepts.name: Audit Execution
business_concepts.description: Audit Execution is the on-site phase of conducting the audit through document review, process observation, interviews, and evidence collection to verify conformance to standards and identify non-conformances. Also referred to as audit performance, on-site audit, or audit conduct.

business_concepts.name: Audit Reporting
business_concepts.description: Audit Reporting is the documentation process of compiling audit findings, non-conformances, observations, and recommendations into a formal audit report with severity classifications and corrective action requirements. Also known as audit documentation, findings report, or audit summary.

business_concepts.name: Audit Follow-Up
business_concepts.description: Audit Follow-Up is the closure process of verifying that corrective actions for audit findings have been completed effectively and documented, and determining if follow-up audits are needed. Also referred to as corrective action verification, audit closure, or findings resolution.

name: Statistical Process Control
description: Statistical Process Control (SPC) is the quality methodology of using statistical charts to monitor process variation over time, detect out-of-control conditions, and ensure processes remain capable of meeting specifications. Also referred to as SPC, control charting, process monitoring, or statistical quality control.

business_concepts.name: Control Chart Setup
business_concepts.description: Control Chart Setup is the initial process of selecting appropriate control chart types (X-bar R, X-mR, p, c, u), calculating control limits from baseline data, and establishing sampling plans for ongoing monitoring. Also known as SPC implementation, chart creation, or control limit calculation.

business_concepts.name: SPC Data Collection
business_concepts.description: SPC Data Collection is the ongoing measurement process of taking samples at defined intervals, recording measurements, plotting points on control charts, and documenting observations during production. Also referred to as process sampling, data plotting, or measurement recording.

business_concepts.name: Out-of-Control Detection
business_concepts.description: Out-of-Control Detection is the analysis process of applying statistical rules to control charts to identify when processes exhibit non-random variation indicating special causes that require investigation and correction. Also known as special cause detection, control chart interpretation, or process alarm.

business_concepts.name: Process Capability Analysis
business_concepts.description: Process Capability Analysis is the statistical calculation of process capability indices (Cp, Cpk, Pp, Ppk) comparing process variation to specification limits to determine if processes can consistently produce conforming products. Also referred to as capability study, Cpk analysis, or process capability assessment.

name: Calibration
description: Calibration is the process of adjusting and verifying measuring equipment and test instruments against known standards to ensure accuracy, reliability, and traceability of measurements used in quality control. Also referred to as equipment calibration, gauge calibration, measurement verification, or instrument calibration.

business_concepts.name: Calibration Scheduling
business_concepts.description: Calibration Scheduling is the maintenance planning process of establishing calibration frequencies, generating work orders for due calibrations, scheduling appointments with calibration labs, and sending advance notifications to equipment owners. Also known as calibration planning, PM scheduling for gauges, or calibration calendar management.

business_concepts.name: Calibration Execution
business_concepts.description: Calibration Execution is the technical process of performing calibration procedures including as-found readings, adjustments if needed, as-left readings, comparing to tolerances, and generating calibration certificates. Also referred to as calibration performance, gauge verification, or equipment standardization.

business_concepts.name: Calibration Record Management
business_concepts.description: Calibration Record Management is the documentation process of maintaining calibration certificates, tracking calibration history, storing traceability documentation, and providing records for audits and compliance verification. Also known as calibration documentation, metrology records, or calibration history tracking.

business_concepts.name: Equipment Lockout
business_concepts.description: Equipment Lockout is the quality control process of marking and removing overdue or failed measuring equipment from service to prevent use of uncalibrated or inaccurate instruments that could produce invalid measurements. Also referred to as gauge hold, equipment quarantine, or out-of-service marking.

name: Customer Complaint
description: A Customer Complaint is formal feedback from customers about product defects, quality issues, delivery problems, or service dissatisfaction requiring investigation, response, and corrective action. Also referred to as customer quality issue, quality complaint, customer feedback, or field failure.

business_concepts.name: Complaint Receipt
business_concepts.description: Complaint Receipt is the customer service process of capturing customer complaints through multiple channels (phone, email, portal), documenting details, assigning case numbers, and routing to quality for investigation. Also known as complaint logging, issue intake, or complaint registration.

business_concepts.name: Complaint Investigation
business_concepts.description: Complaint Investigation is the quality analysis process of examining returned products, reviewing production records, interviewing personnel, and determining root causes of customer-reported problems. Also referred to as complaint analysis, failure investigation, or root cause determination.

business_concepts.name: Customer Response
business_concepts.description: Customer Response is the communication process of acknowledging complaints, explaining investigation findings, describing corrective actions, and resolving customer concerns to restore satisfaction. Also known as complaint closure, customer notification, or response letter.

business_concepts.name: Trend Analysis
business_concepts.description: Trend Analysis is the quality monitoring process of aggregating customer complaints by product, defect type, or customer to identify systemic quality issues requiring broader corrective actions beyond individual complaint resolution. Also referred to as complaint trending, pattern analysis, or field failure analysis.

name: Supplier Quality
description: Supplier Quality encompasses the quality management activities focused on ensuring suppliers deliver materials and components that meet specifications and performance requirements. Also referred to as supplier quality management, incoming quality, vendor quality, or supply chain quality.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Quality Agreement
business_concepts.description: Supplier Quality Agreement is the contract process of establishing quality requirements, inspection procedures, defect definitions, reporting obligations, and corrective action processes with suppliers. Also known as quality terms, SQA, or quality expectations.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Quality Rating
business_concepts.description: Supplier Quality Rating is the performance measurement process of calculating supplier quality scores based on defect rates, lot rejection rates, and corrective action responsiveness to drive accountability. Also referred to as supplier scorecard, quality metrics, or supplier evaluation.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Quality Issue Resolution
business_concepts.description: Supplier Quality Issue Resolution is the collaborative process of working with suppliers to investigate incoming material defects, implement corrective actions, and verify effectiveness through 8D or CAPA methodologies. Also known as supplier corrective action, quality collaboration, or supplier CAPA.

business_concepts.name: Supplier Quality Development
business_concepts.description: Supplier Quality Development is the improvement program where buyers provide technical assistance, training, or resources to help suppliers enhance quality capabilities and prevent recurring defects. Also referred to as supplier improvement, quality coaching, or capability building.
